name: LumLum
address: 404 W 49th St, New York, NY 10019, USA

reviews.text: Wonderful!! I love this place
very nice food, great service, and will come back )

Best Thai food I've ever had!
Everything was great except the size of the table.
It was a bit tight for 4 ppl
Excellent signature cocktails! I will eat here next time! Thai seafood menu.
The food was great! Especially the pad kee map, cute outfits and vibe

Do you ever read reviews and wonder if you went to the same place? Thatâ€™s me right now.

The staff were not friendly and not attentive. The tables are very close together.

I havenâ€™t had a drink in two years so I expected the mai tai to hit me. Instead, Iâ€™m not sure it contained any alcohol. It wasnâ€™t particularly good - my friend only drank half of hers.

The pas Thai wasnâ€™t particularly flavorful. I donâ€™t like spice, but itâ€™s possible to be non-spicy and flavorful; this was just bland.

Two positives:
1. Food was served extremely quickly.
2. Itâ€™s very close to the theatres.
Love the ambiance. Everything was amazing, specially love the steamed branzino.
Drinks were fun and food was good!

We really love the food cooked here. We ordered Goong Yang grilled pawn and a white curry beef stew with Brussels sprouts, b/c I can't handle spicy food. They came out with balanced taste and well cooked good food materials.
Highly recommend this restaurant!! Itâ€™s a great place for friends to hangout and the food is really really delicious!!!
Great place, amazing food!(:
Food was so good and felt authentic !! Dessert is FIRE!
Food was super yummy and great ambience!
Excellent food and great service! Would come back again
good food
Very delicious food and cute place! Very nice service too
Great restaurant!
Amazing food and the vibes were great
Amazing food and really cute atmosphere
Super good food, super good service!
The food and service was great! Can recommended by a friend and well deserved
Authentic Thai food in the heart of Hellâ€™s kitchen! With so many options nearby LumLum is truly a stand out. The prawn appetizer was amazing and so fresh - loved my green martini!
Great food and great cocktails. We loved the fried whole fish, Kao soi and papaya salad.  Everything was tasty!
Love the food options. Great service. Would come back again for their other menu options.
Tasty and rich flavor, I recommendðŸ˜Š
yummy food very flavorful! Great atmosphere and warm environment.
Ped Pad Prik was excellent. Lovely spot for some Thai food in Hellâ€™s Kitchen.
Delicious, ambient, and authentic! The panang curry was exquisite â€” highly recommend.

Love LumLum - one of the best tom yum goongs in the city. Itâ€™s creamy and spicy with the meatiest shrimp. I also recommend the panang neue, itâ€™s also a tad spicy with a delicious steak to top it off

The staff is always so lovely and the interior feels like a vacation to Thailand -  always love coming back here ðŸ’•
desert is very good, highly recommend!
Perfect food! I like the fish dish and curry soft crab
Very friendly staff and a good atmosphere. The food was divine, and the branzino was great. The curry was quite spicy which is good. I don't think there was a single bad dish.
Super cute restaurant, food was great, drinks were very creative and delicious
Lum Lum is truly a delight, the servers are kind and the service is quick. The food gives a really authentic vibe ,as if each dish was cooked over an open flame and placed right in front of you

Iâ€™m still eating and I had to stop and write a review - Iâ€™ve never had such delicious food. Iâ€™ve eaten at every Thai restaurant on the west side and Iâ€™ve never had food like this. Get the ped pad prik. Crying tiger and khao pad gak moo were also delicious!
Best Thai place in the city!! I have come back here so many times love the vibe and the food!!!
we had the pad thai and chive dumplings. so delicious and loved the atmosphere

Hands down the best thai food in town, I never had a bad meal here. I especially enjoy their thai basil minced meat with rice, it's so good I always crave it. Their dessert and drinks are also tasty and perfect for their cozy yet stylish set-up.
Been to LumLum a few times and all the food and drinks Iâ€™ve gotten are so good!
The food here is amazing and the staff is super friendly. Had the best time. This is one of my go to spots.
A regular in my friends and Iâ€™s city dinner rotation! Incredible food, friendly staff, and clean restaurant. Be sure to stop by!
Really yummy Thai food, not too busy, and cocktails are interesting too! Recommend the khao soi, the crying tiger (beef dish), and the steamed fish!
Good food, great service!
very good!
yummy :)
Loved the crispy duck curry
Super yummy! We got the Crying Tiger as a recommendation from the LumLum team and it was really delicious.

We tried this after starving for hours because we had to make a broadway show. The service was great and everyone was nice and they were able to accommodate our bigger party as quick as they could. Our server gave us great recommendations and constantly was attentive to us. The food was great and would highly recommend the Crying Tiger and Pad Thai!
Amazing food and even better service! Crying tiger drink and steak were 10/10.

Nestled away along a corner of 9th ave, this bustling thai restaurant adds life to what normally is a quiet street. We ordered the crab fried rice, pad see ew and crying tiger and each dish was very delicious. The crispy onions on the crying tiger perfectly complimented the sweet bed of rice and the lime sauce that came with the crab fried rice added a nice acidity. Would happily come back to try other dishes

I had a good experience at Lum Lum! The food was delicious â€” the dumplings were super tasty, and the Pad Thai was beautifully presented and full of flavor. The restaurant is nicely decorated and has a great vibe.

The only thing is that the tables are quite close to each other, so itâ€™s not the best spot for a quiet or intimate dinner. But overall, the atmosphere is really nice, and the food makes it totally worth it. Iâ€™d definitely go back!

It has been a while since Iâ€™ve been upset with a meal while dining out. My mood was literally ruined while I was having this meal, which made this meal less enjoyable. The fresh branzino (steamed) that arrived this morning (recommended by the waiter) had a lot of bones and has more of a fish taste than Iâ€™d like. Also while you serve out the food from this dish, you need to be super careful and make sure you donâ€™t tilt or spill the contents in the dish. Iâ€™d recommend this fish dish for anyone who really enjoys bones and likes the taste of fish. My husband really enjoyed the fish though.

And the moon cocktail (waiter said this was his favorite cocktail so of course I had to give it a try) came at the end of our meal (and I had to ask twice for it prior, and asked for it to be cancelled because we were almost done with our meal) when it was the first thing that we ordered. When I wanted to cancel the cocktail order, they made it almost immediately. It had such a strong rum taste; I barely tasted any of the coconut flavor or any of the other ingredients in that drink. I only had like two sips of it and gave the rest to my husband.

The chives and shrimp dumplings (recommended by the waiter) had a nice mochi skin texture, but barely had any shrimp in it. The pad kee mao had a good amount of seafood and tasted okay. When the waiter asked how everything was, I originally said that everything was okay, but when he asked a second time, I said, â€œCan I be honest with you? The fish has a lot of bones and is hard to eat and the cocktail really shouldnâ€™t have came at the end of the meal.â€ He was very apologetic and said that the cocktail was of no charge and that if we would like, they can remove the charge of the fish too. But since my husband liked the fish, we said itâ€™s fine, we will pay for the fish. He probably saw how upset I was at the meal, he brought out homemade complimentary coconut ice cream at the end of the meal for us. That ice cream was yummy and did make me feel better.

We sat at one of the tables outside of the restaurant - if you want to be surrounded by the nyc traffic noise, loud passerbys and essentially have the classic hustle bustle nyc dining experience, this setting would be good for it. But if youâ€™re looking for a more calm, relaxing and quiet meal, this might not satisfy your needs.

Anyway, as Iâ€™m writing this review, Iâ€™m thankful for the follow-up service that the waiter provided to try to make my experience better. Iâ€™ve learned that what is recommended is not always suitable. I am most likely not going to be coming back here any time soon.

I saw the impressive high ratings on Google map and decided to try it. I mean, 4.8 over 3K review. It gotta be so good. Well, maybe my expectations were too high. The food was good. But not like â€˜omg this is so amazingâ€™ good. Thatâ€™s why I took a star off.

We ordered a bunch of stuff. My personal no. 1 is the ton yum soup. The steamed fish was pretty good but the fish could be fresher. My group really liked the rice with the steak but it didnâ€™t stand out to me. We also got taro cake and crispy pork belly. Pretty decent.

It was quite loud in a small space. The staff are friendly and attentive. I would go back if I happen to be in that area.

WOW. Some of the best Thai food Iâ€™ve ever had. Would highly recommend their Fried Pork Belly as an appetizer, as well as their Pork Rind Fried Rice, though everything we tried was incredible. Thai Iced Tea and Coffee are both delicious! Recommend a reservation, as it fills up quickly once it opens. Looking forward to coming again soon.
We ordered our serverâ€™s recommendations and we were not disappointed! The steamed fish and crying tiger was absolutely delicious. Our server was attentive and respectful. Definitely coming back.

We left the conference with that classic New York plan: â€œquick bite before the airport.â€ Famous last words. My colleague spotted LumLum Thai, I checked the clock, and we both agreed we had exactly the right amount of time to eat responsibly and act like adults. The host told us 15 minutes. Perfect. Fifteen became a gentle exhale: a short line, the scent of lime and chilies drifting from the pass, and the pleasant clatter of a tiny room running at full clip.

Inside, LumLum is small in the good wayâ€”a handful of tight tables, a slim banquette, and a lane just wide enough for servers to slide by with that New York ballet step that keeps water glasses upright. The palette is warmâ€”pale wood, woven textures, a couple of leafy plants doing their partâ€”while low pendant lights make the place feel like golden hour even when it isnâ€™t. You catch spurts of Thai pop under the roomâ€™s conversation and the steady sizzle from the kitchen window. Itâ€™s the kind of shoebox that asks you to lean in and actually talk to the person across from you. We did.

We started with the fried porkâ€”little bronzed pieces that snapped clean at the edge and stayed juicy in the middle. The coating had that crackly rice-flour crunch, lightly seasonedâ€”pepper, garlicâ€”so the pork didnâ€™t need a speech to make its point. The dipping sauce was bright and bossyâ€”chili, lime, a fish-sauce winkâ€”like someone bottled the idea of wakefulness. We â€œsharedâ€ it in the way people say â€œweâ€ when one of them is clearly doing more than half the sharing.

For my main, I went curry with steak. It arrived with a confident, coconut-chili sheen and those citrus-lift aromatics that suggest kaffir lime without announcing themselves like a keynote. The steak was sliced blushing medium, rested properly so it absorbed the curry instead of swimming on top of it. Heat built slowlyâ€”not a dare, just a handshake that firmed up as you went. The jasmine rice did its job like a great bass line: supportive, a little fragrant, exactly where you need it when your spoon keeps returning to the bowl.

Across the table, my colleague ordered a calamari dish over very thin noodlesâ€”a tangle of rice vermicelli that carried a light, glossy sauce. The calamari had that rare tender bounce (no rubber bands today), and you could taste the wokâ€™s quick kissâ€”just a hint of charâ€”pulling sweetness from scallions and herbs. It was clean, bright, and the kind of plate you â€œsampleâ€ once and then keep sampling as if itâ€™s a scientific study.

Service ran snappy and kind. Menus down, waters refilled, spice levels calibrated with a simple, â€œDo you want us to make it sing?â€ They did, and it did. Plates landed in a rhythm that respected conversationâ€”enough time to notice details, never enough to wonder where anything was.

Then came the part where we forgot the airport exists. The roomâ€™s hum, the light, the way the curryâ€™s heat lingered just long enough to keep you talkingâ€”it all conspired to stretch the evening. The flight to Buffalo did what flights sometimes do when you treat time like a suggestion: it left without us. We shrugged, finished the last forkfuls, and ordered water like the responsible people we briefly were at the beginning of this story.

Verdict: LumLum is the kind of tiny New York restaurant that punches way above its square footageâ€”a place where the food is precise, the flavors feel alive, and the ambiance convinces you that schedules are flexible. Get the fried pork. If you like a good, layered heat, get the steak curry. If you prefer lighter and herbal, borrow (steal) bites of the calamari with thin noodles. And if youâ€™re headed to the airport afterward, pad the calendar. This little room is very good at making you forget you own a calendar at all.

Delicious and scrumptious!! Pad see ew and pad Thai were all so yummy. Crying tiger was also good but I was more blown away by the noodles. Such a flavorful Thai spot with great vibes too!! (Iâ€™m ngl weâ€™re getting free dessert to write this review but itâ€™s actually really good so I donâ€™t even mind)

We had such a great experience here! We ordered the siam smiles (lychee martinis), goong yang, and crying tiger to share, and everything was delicious. The flavors were fresh and perfectly balanced. The drinks were just as good as the food. Great atmosphere for our group of friends to catch up and enjoy a meal together!
I loved the Seafood Tom Yum Noodle - the flavor of it was really unique and tasty. The crying tiger was good. Every dish was wow! Iâ€™m very eager to come again and try more new food.

The crying tiger was everything I needed it to be. And the orange salad was such a good combination. I think my waitress name was Gali and she was so sweet. I love it when servers donâ€™t make it awkward when I dine in alone. The service here is amazing. I canâ€™t wait to eat my leftovers. I will definitely be coming back!

Simply WOW. The best Thai food Iâ€™ve ever had: the Green Duck Curry was out of this world, the Shrimp Pad Thai was simply the best Iâ€™ve ever had, the Crying Tiger rice was aaaammmaaazzzinnngggg. Iâ€™ll definitely come back and recommend to all my friends
(Pics of the before and after for reference on how good it was!)

Yum! Been meaning to try this restaurant for a while and finally stopped by on a Friday afternoon. We had a reservation but didnâ€™t really need it.

We had Moo Krob, Gai Tod Khamin, Crying Tiger, and Steamed Fish with Lime and Herbs.   The steamed branzino was my fave! Not pictured, but recommended are lychee juice and Thai iced tea.
Last minute find but was pleasantly surprised! Everything last fantastic and the green sauce that comes with the shrimp is really good. Ate the whole meal with that sauce.

The crying tiger and duck were delicious. The garlic rice was very flavorful as well. The mango on mango sticky rice was good. The service was good too. Would recommend trying this place out. Suitable for a small party of 1-4.

It is so cute in here! We got the pad see ew (best ive had), crab and pumpkin curry, and pork cracklin fried rice. Will have to come back for the cocktails, everything on the tables around us looked so good!!

Good thai food. Came on a busy Saturday night dinner. Restaurant is on the small side with alot of seating, so it felt little loud and crammed. The food overall was good. Pad thai was delicious and so were other dishes. The steak over garlic rice was good but the steak itself was a bit tough.

Iâ€™ve had this place on my list for years and boy did it exceed my expectations. This was hands down the best Pad Thai Iâ€™ve ever had - we got the beef. It was so juicy and flavorful as was the fried pork belly and steamed branzino. The drinks were nicely sized and delicious. I loved the ambience - felt like an episode of white lotus. Hands down my new favorite Thai spot.

Ordered the Pad Ki Mao, they werenâ€™t kidding with the thai spicy. Tastes like a spicier version of pad see ew, but with MUCH better and juicier chicken. Was rlly looking forward to mango sticky rice and they ran out so I have to come back. Very cool and trendy place.

I have been ordering delivery from here for quite a while as I work nearby. Unfortunately the quality has been steadily decreasing the last few months. It started with a change in the seafood, I figured it was a change in supplier but it used to be so much more fresh. My Pad Ki Mao now is just blanched subpar seafood with mushy rice noodles. Thereâ€™s no char from the wok that I used to love. Sadly this is not worth the price for the quality anymore.

Iâ€™ve also had other dishes in person like the steak which is not worth it in my opinion. But their seafood dishes were amazing. Not sure how it is now.

Iâ€™m posting a picture of what the Pad Ki Mao currently looks like (Oct 2025) and what it used to be (Feb 2025)
Came here for a coworkerâ€™s birthday. Food is good, atmosphere is nice might be a bit hard to talk but it all good. Small place, kinda stuffy for big guys.

I dropped by Lum Lum in Hellâ€™s Kitchen and finally got to try the Crying Tiger Special and Moo Grob. The Crying Tiger was legit! Couldâ€™ve used a bit more kick, but the dipping sauce lowkey saved it. The Moo Grob was so crispy, not too greasy. The whole place has a chill, no-fuss energy, which Iâ€™m into. Itâ€™s not trying to be overly aesthetic, but still cute enough to bring a friend or a date. Prices didnâ€™t hurt, and the staff were super friendly but not all over you.
Definitely one of those spots Iâ€™d hit up again when Iâ€™m craving Thai comfort food without doing the most.

Amazing service by the staff. Interior is beautiful, feels like hut on tropical island. food was delicious but my steak was slightly cold and chewy but itâ€™s understand since probably cooked before the order is even placed. Every dish was aesthetically pleasing, def recommend the mango sticky rice

The experience dining at this restaurant was really lovely.

Food: I ordered the Khao Soi Gai with a Thai Iced Tea. Everything tasted delicious and fresh. The food was filling and well seasoned.

Staff: The staff was very friendly and attentive.

Price: The price was great for the location, service, and quality of the ingredients.

It was easy to make a reservation at this restaurant (recommended). I enjoyed sitting next to the big floor to ceiling windows.

I would definitely visit again.

Overall great food, but was too spicy for me. The pumpkin curry is delicious with pumpkin slices and soft shell crab. Tomyum is well seasoned. I really like the roti; it's crispy. The dessert is okay. The ice cream with salted egg is interesting, but the rice balls is too soft. The place gets quite crowded during late afternoon/dinner time so reservation is recommended.
Great spot with many interesting options. Friends loved the drinks and the dessert was so unique! Will come back. We received one free dessert as well for a review!

Really friendly (and well dressed servers)! The Fighting Tiger (ribeye with garlic fried rice and an egg yolk) was bomb, and the drunken noodles were really well seasoned (not drenched in soy). Would highly recommend the beef tartare.

Got two drinks; everything was reasonably priced, and we had bar counter seats, which let us watch the assortment of the drinks on the menu being made.

Walked in Friday night â€” outdoor wait was around 20 minutes and indoor table for two 45 minutes. Bar seats no wait

The taro mochi ball with coconut ice cream and salted egg is one of the best desserts I've had in a while. Perfect contrasts of texture and temperature with all the classic thai dessert flavors. We also really enjoyed the khao soi and green curry with duck. The khao soi is one of the best we've had outside of chang mai. We'll be back!
The service was exceptional and the food was authentically delicious! Iâ€™ve been here a few times and keep coming back with my loved ones. My go to is the papaya salad and beef Pad Thai!

Food was good! Ordered the pork belly, duck, crab fried rice, and a veggie dish. Really enjoyed the tender duck and slightly crispy skin. Good ambiance. Restaurant felt a little cramped but thereâ€™s plenty of table seating. The place is split in two separate rooms.

Was in NYC for the night and snagged a reservation at LumLum! The service was incredible.

We started with an espresso martini, nothing spectacular but got the job done. Couldâ€™ve done without the cinnamon, but thats a personal preference. We also got the goong yang, prawns. The spicy chili lime dressing was delectable! Loved the dish.

For our mains, we got the crying tiger and khao soi gai. We unfortunately sent the crying tiger back, the meat was so chewy and cold. We saw rave reviews about it, so that was surprising. The khao soi gai was one of the best things Iâ€™ve ever ate. The seasonings and flavor in each bite was addicting. The chicken fell off the bone, noodles cooked perfectly, absolutely no notes.

We swapped out the crying tiger for the nam ya poo. I personally couldnâ€™t eat this because of how spicy it was, but my partner did and he absolutely loved it. Only get this if you can handle some serious heat!

The service was attentive and friendly, they were on top of providing water, fresh plates/silverware, etc. Small restaurant but a nice ambiance. I would definitely come back!
